Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Trans people, just like everyone else, want to be able to travel, start new jobs, open bank accounts, enroll in school, vote — all of those things require some form of ID.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: explained by Lucas Cameron-Vaughn, an attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee, to illustrate the challenges faced by trans individuals

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Gender nonconforming people are already under such public scrutiny nationwide.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: mentioned by Quinn Diaz to highlight the increased scrutiny faced by this group

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Cisgender women... are the people harmed by protections for trans people.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: referenced by Rose Saxe to describe a tactic used by politicians supporting anti-trans policies

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Black and Hispanic people... are among those most likely not to have a current license.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: according to the Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland, to highlight the impact of ID requirements

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: At least nine states in the past two years have explicitly regulated gender in this way, according to a tally by the Movement Advancement Project (MAP), which tracks LGBTQ+ policy.
Document Sources.Source Justification: cited as a source for tracking LGBTQ+ policy

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The Williams Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Law, estimated ahead of the 2022 midterm election that more than 200,000 voting-eligible transgender Americans may find it difficult to vote at the time because of voter ID laws.
Document Sources.Name of Source: The Williams Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Law
Document Sources.Source Justification: referenced for estimating the impact of voter ID laws on trans Americans

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: An analysis released in August of respondents to the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey, widely seen as the most comprehensive study of binary and nonbinary transgender Americans, found that voting-eligible trans people had cast ballots in the last presidential election at a higher rate than the U.S. population.
Document Sources.Source Justification: cited as the most comprehensive study of binary and nonbinary transgender Americans

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: There is a chilling effect... There is an unsafe and intimidating environment around existing as trans in society, and definitely in being able to go to the polls safely and cast a ballot.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and Executive Director of VoteRiders
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: quoted to highlight the impact of anti-trans laws on trans voters

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: A lot is falling on poll workers to correctly enforce the law... And I would argue that is less of a solid protection in states where anti-trans rhetoric is skyrocketing.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and Executive Director of VoteRiders
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: quoted to emphasize the challenges faced by poll workers

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Trans votes count... I think the big takeaway is that our community is really trying to come out and make a difference through the democratic process.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Director of Research for the National Center for Transgender Equality
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: quoted to highlight the importance of trans votes

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Trans people, just like everyone else, want to be able to travel, start new jobs, open bank accounts, enroll in school, vote — all of those things require some form of ID.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: quoted to explain the challenges faced by trans individuals

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: It’s a tactic that’s designed to splinter support for trans rights and suggest sort of who is harmed by protecting trans people — to frame that as cisgender women being the people harmed by protections for trans people.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Deputy Project Director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: quoted to describe a tactic used by politicians supporting anti-trans policies

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: We saw it as a move to inflict maximum chaos and misunderstanding... And really to scare trans folks from even participating and getting the license if they needed to update it.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public Policy Associate at Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: quoted to describe the impact of Florida's new gender marker regulation

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: With these laws in Florida, you’re forced to choose between living authentically and just not really participating in public life.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public Policy Associate at Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: quoted to highlight the challenges faced by trans individuals in Florida

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: There’s nothing these laws will do to stop me from living my best life... It just puts my energy and passion towards making this place better for me and other trans people.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: quoted to share her personal experience and determination

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: It really shows the resiliency of the trans community to ensure that our voices are heard and we have visibility at the ballot box.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: quoted to highlight the resilience of the trans community

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union have drafted a letter reminding election workers that a gender marker on a person’s identification does not need to match or correspond to a voter’s gender expression.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: mentioned as taking action to support trans voters

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Staff for the organization have also held clinics elsewhere to prepare trans Americans for the identification requirements they will have to navigate.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: mentioned as providing support to trans Americans

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The ACLU sued the agency for discrimination, claiming the rule was adopted illegally because it didn’t follow proper administrative procedure.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: mentioned as taking legal action against discriminatory rules

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: VoteRiders is on the ground helping voters get the identification they need to cast ballots in the November election — and one that reflects who they are.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: mentioned as providing support to voters

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Equality Florida, the state’s leading LGBTQ+ advocacy group, is holding “know your rights” trainings in the wake of new regulations barring many transgender voters from obtaining photo identification that reflects their gender.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: mentioned as providing support to trans voters in Florida

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland, whose research was partially supported by VoteRiders, found that nearly 21 million voting-eligible U.S. citizens do not have a current driver’s license.
Named Organization Sources.Name of Source: Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: cited as a source for research on voter ID requirements
